questions.stem: What should you check during a pre-drive vehicle inspection?

choices.text: Tires, lights, windshield, wiper blades, and fluid leaks
Just the fuel level and radio
Only the seat position and mirrors

questions.explanation: A thorough pre-drive inspection includes checking tires for proper inflation and damage, all lights (headlights, taillights, brake lights, turn signals), windshield and windows for cracks or dirt, wiper blade condition, and looking for fluid leaks under the vehicle.

questions.stem: What is the correct hand position on the steering wheel for maximum control?

choices.text: Both A and B are correct

questions.explanation: Both 9 and 3 o'clock and 10 and 2 o'clock positions are correct for maximum steering control. These positions allow for quick steering movements and maintain proper control of the vehicle.

questions.stem: Before starting the engine, what should you ensure?

choices.text: The parking brake is engaged and gear selector is in Park/Neutral

questions.explanation: Before starting the engine, ensure the parking brake is engaged and the gear selector is in Park (automatic) or Neutral (manual). This prevents the vehicle from moving unexpectedly when starting.

questions.stem: When should you use hand-over-hand steering?

choices.text: Only for sharp turns and parking maneuvers

questions.explanation: Hand-over-hand steering is used for sharp turns and parking maneuvers where you need maximum steering control. For normal driving and gradual turns, push-pull steering is more efficient.

questions.stem: What is progressive acceleration?

choices.text: Starting gently and increasing pressure gradually

questions.explanation: Progressive acceleration means starting gently and increasing pressure gradually. This saves fuel, provides better control, and is safer than sudden acceleration.

questions.stem: How much stopping distance do you need at 40 mph on dry pavement?
questions.explanation: At 40 mph, you need approximately 120 feet to stop on dry pavement. This includes both reaction time and braking distance. The distance increases significantly in poor weather conditions.

questions.stem: How do you apply the 3-second rule?

choices.text: Pick a fixed object ahead and count 'one-thousand-one, one-thousand-two, one-thousand-three' when the vehicle ahead passes it
Drive 3 mph slower than the vehicle ahead

questions.explanation: Pick a fixed object ahead (like a sign or tree). When the vehicle in front of you passes it, count 'one-thousand-one, one-thousand-two, one-thousand-three.' If you reach the object before finishing, you're following too closely.

questions.stem: How often should you check your mirrors while driving?

choices.text: Every 5-8 seconds and before any maneuver

questions.explanation: Check your mirrors every 5-8 seconds and before any maneuver. This keeps you aware of what's happening around your vehicle and helps maintain situational awareness.

questions.stem: What should you do to check your blind spot before changing lanes?

choices.text: Turn your head and look over your shoulder

questions.explanation: Always turn your head and look over your shoulder to check your blind spot before changing lanes. This is called a shoulder check and is crucial because mirrors can't show you everything.

questions.stem: What is a space cushion?

choices.text: The area around your vehicle that you keep clear of other vehicles

questions.explanation: A space cushion is the area around your vehicle that you keep clear of other vehicles. This gives you room to maneuver if something unexpected happens and provides a safety zone.

questions.stem: Which type of turn is generally easier and safer?
questions.explanation: Right turns are generally easier and safer than left turns because you don't need to cross oncoming traffic. You only need to yield to pedestrians and cyclists.

questions.stem: In California, how far in advance must you signal before turning if traveling under 35 mph?
questions.explanation: In California, you must signal at least 100 feet before turning if traveling under 35 mph, or 200 feet if traveling 35 mph or faster. This gives other drivers adequate notice of your intentions.

questions.stem: What does a complete stop at a stop sign mean?

choices.text: Your wheels must actually stop moving

questions.explanation: A complete stop means your wheels must actually stop moving. Rolling through a stop sign is illegal and dangerous. You must come to a full stop before proceeding.

questions.stem: When parking uphill with a curb, which direction should you turn your wheels?
questions.explanation: When parking uphill with a curb, turn your wheels away from the curb (left). This way, if your vehicle rolls, it will roll into the curb and stop, rather than into traffic.

questions.stem: What is the minimum space needed for parallel parking?

choices.text: The same length as your car
At least 1.5 times the length of your car
Twice the length of your car
Half the length of your car

questions.explanation: For parallel parking, you need a space that's at least 1.5 times the length of your car. This gives you enough room to maneuver into the space safely.

questions.stem: What should you do before backing up?

choices.text: Walk around your vehicle to check for obstacles, children, or animals

questions.explanation: Before backing up, walk around your vehicle to check for obstacles, children, or animals. Use your mirrors and turn your head to look behind you. Backing up is dangerous due to limited visibility.

questions.stem: What does the 'S' in SMOG stand for?
questions.explanation: SMOG stands for Signal, Mirrors, Over-the-shoulder, Go. The 'S' stands for Signal - turn on your turn signal to let other drivers know your intention to change lanes.

questions.stem: When merging onto a freeway, what should you do?

choices.text: Expect other drivers to slow down for you
Accelerate to match the speed of traffic on the freeway
Merge at a much slower speed

questions.explanation: When merging onto a freeway, accelerate to match the speed of traffic on the freeway. Don't merge at a much slower speed - this creates a dangerous situation. You must yield to traffic already on the freeway.

questions.stem: What should you do if you see a vehicle in your blind spot when trying to change lanes?

choices.text: Speed up and change lanes quickly
Force your way into the lane

questions.explanation: If you see a vehicle in your blind spot, wait until it passes before changing lanes. Don't force your way into traffic. Only change lanes when it's safe to do so.

questions.stem: When exiting a freeway, when should you move to the right lane?

choices.text: After you see the exit sign

questions.explanation: When exiting a freeway, signal early and move to the right lane well before your exit. Don't cut across multiple lanes at the last minute, which is dangerous and illegal.
